conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks a light source.
The size and shape of the shadow depend on the position and distance of the light source relative to the object and the surface.
A closer light source will cause the shadows to become larger because the angle at which the light rays hit the objects increases.
As the light source moves downward, the direction of the light rays changes, causing the shadows to shift closer to the objects.
The shadows will increase in size because the light rays spread out more when the source is closer, covering a larger area on the ground.
The shape of the shadows will remain similar to the objects but will appear more diffused and larger.
Shadow A moves closer to the base of the milkshake and becomes larger.
Shadow B moves closer to the typewriter and expands.
Shadow C moves closer to the ball and grows larger.
Shadow D moves closer to the base of the triangular object and increases.
Final Answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will shift closer to their respective objects and increase in size.
